newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela sells 70.68 bln bolivars of TEM bills.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela sells 70.68 bln bolivars of TEM bills.

text.p: Venezuela's Central Bank said it sold 64.24 billion bolivars of 177-day "monetary stabilization", or TEM, bills at a price of 97.79 pct.
The 177-day bills carried a 23.86 percent coupon.

The bank also sold 4.35 billion bolivars of 269-day notes with a 24.57 percent coupon at a price of 95.30 percent, and 1.90 billion bolivars of 358-day notes with a 25.29 percent coupon at an average price of 92.83 percent.
The Bank had offered 80 billion bolivars of 177-day notes, 27 billion of 269-day notes and 28 billion of 358-day bills.

According to a preliminary calculation by Reuters that uses the Central Bank formula, the yield on the notes was 28.99 percent for the 177-day TEMs, 32.36 percent for the 269-day notes, and 35.01 percent for the 358-day TEMs.
The yields for 177-, 269-, and 358-day bills rose at last week's auction to 23.85 percent, 27.87 percent and 30.22 percent respectively.
The weekly TEM bill auctions are the Central Bank's principal tool of monetary policy, used to restrict liquidity and establish a benchmark for wider interest rates.
